by your logic they should introduce different pricing schemes for non-fat, 2% and whole milk since each of these requires different containers and approaches.
author: A. E.

description: whatever. not starbucks. not cool. but it's coffee.
author: Denise C.

description: The staff are all super friendly. I don't know how they remember so many customers' names. The coffee tends to be a little stronger here than at Starbucks. Lots of excellent pastry options. A great neighborhood coffee place.
author: Daniel N.

description: Yesterday, was my first time going into Martha and Bros and I had a fabulous experience. I wanted a smoothie and they recommended the PIna Colada. Andy made it for me, real nice guy, and was very conversational. I felt like I have been knowing him since FOREVER!  Overall I had a great experience, the cafe had a nice ambiance!
author: Rosa T.

description: a friend and i have come here twice, on the board tea is listed for $1.50 but after making the expensive tea they hand it to you and ask for more money. cause they say its the whole leaf tea. when asked why its not the price listed on the board they say its cause they used the whole leaf tea and insist you pay more. rude service.
author: Satoshi K.

description: This is my favorite Martha's in the city.  Outstanding coffee, surprisingly good bagel with lox, nice benches outside to soak up a foggy morning in SF.
author: John W.

description:
Love Martha Brothers Coffee! You often find yourself in a pretty large crowd when you come up to the shop but I'm always pleased with how quickly I have my coffee and am out the door. The staff is so warm and friendly- definitely no bad attitude coffee served here!

The coffee is great, lattes are done right every time and they have a lot of really great food! I am a serious addict of the pumpkin muffins (and so are other people since they are often sold out). Definitely a great choice for your go to coffee place.
author: Karyn S.

description:
probably the best coffee house in noe valley...

i'm not a big fan of noe valley. it's too clean. it's too sterile. it's too bland. it reminds me of that neighborhood in the northern part of frisco. so i like to slum it in the mission. however, my dog (hi elvis!) loves noe valley, especially 24th street. he thinks it's all urban and stuff with shops, bars, restaurants.......and toy dogs.

so i often cave in to his wish and take him to 24th street for a lazy stroll. there he likes to terrorize other dogs and attack little babies and kids. attack, attack, attack!!! rrrrrrr!!! good boy!!! pound for pound, my boy is the toughest dog ever! i'm so proud of him.

then after the mayhem, we like to stop by martha's coffee and frighten away the customers in line. attack, attack, attack!!! rrrrrrr!!! good boy!!!.......oh, hi, one medium coffee please. thank you.

the coffee is pretty good here. not ritual coffee good, but certainly better than starbucks or tully's, which are a few blocks down the street. and the staff is friendly although i suspect they're just scared of my boy. i'm so proud of him.
author: frisco j.

description: Martha is the quintessential entrepreneur. She's a warm professional who understands and caters to the needs of her community. The products are homemade, fresh and organic.  The staff always remember my name and my order.  I can't live without my morning cup of Martha's.
author: Tak O.

description: I'm not  a big fan of Martha & Bros. in general.  I find their shops to be rundown, and the service apathetic.  The folks here are friendlier, but the place has a sloppy vibe.  I'm not likely to return.
author: Andi T.

description:
Though the ladies in this Noe Valley location do have great, helpful demeanors upon first experiencing the service, I have to say that I was hugely disappointed today.

I went in and ordered "the smallest size"....My exact words, with an emphasis on "smallest".  When I went to receive my coffee I noticed that it surely was not the smallest size, it was in fact a size larger...This size being the standard smallest that you would find at other coffee shops.  When I asked if this was in fact the smallest size, the barista lady responded with "we're phasing out the smallest size, this is the new small, so that's what I charged you for."  As she said this to me she showed me the smallest size cup that I was expecting...There were plenty of those cups to go around.  And did she apologize for her mistake and offer a reimbursement?  No, she didn't.  Great service would have been offering an apology for the mistake and a reimbursement for the size I did not want to pay for.  Great service would have been paying what I wanted to pay, but getting the cup she prepared.  And great service would have certainly been abiding by what was currently written on the menu of available sizes, not by what WILL be happening...If that was in fact true.

No apology, nothing...Just moving on.  I know it's a matter of dollars and cents, but it is a matter and one that matters to me.

I was so excited to have found a cute coffee spot within walking distance of my new home...But now I'm just turned off.  I'll walk a little further for the service I'm accustomed to.  

They do have quite an assortment of pastries...But they are definitely nothing to chat about.  If you don't have the goods, you must have great service.  Fall short on that, and you don't have much of anything.

The second star is for the free wi-fi, hang-out-ability, and because I've had better experiences here before.
author: Susy S.

description: I stop here on the way to work every day.  Excellent coffee and the barristas are fast and friendly.
author: Andrew E.

description: I always heard such amazing things about Martha Bros, and I don't understand it. I've tried quite a few lattes here and they always are wicked strong and they taste burnt. I keep trying it because it's local and I want to support local business, but if I'm going to do that, I'll hit up Ritual down on Valencia. Martha's just not all that.
author: Christy K.

description:
Okay, I'm really picky about my coffee and Martha Bros has BY FAR the most delicious cup of STRONG coffee I think I've ever had. Peets is a consistently good cup as well. The other thing I really like Martha's for is their espresso drinks. Having spent many a year being a barista back in the day when it was not such a glam job by any means, I feel as tho finding a well-made, properly frothed, unscalded latte is impossible anymore. Lattes these days seem to be a cup of scalded steamed milk and a shot of weak espresso. Awful. But Martha's lattes are half milk and half foam, NOT SCALDED, with really strong espresso shots. Mmmm.
One thing I did hear, however, from an ex-fan of Martha's, is that they are pouring whole milk into the half and half containers on the counter. She said she saw it happen consistently. That's pretty darn cheap and snakey if you ask me. However, still the best cup of coffee and latte you can find in the city.
Oh, and excellent staff. Fast and efficient. Very little turn-over which is a good sign.
author: amy b.

description: The Mexican Mocha here is damn good - not as good as my at home Ibarra version - but damn good. And a good place to get stroller advice, just like everywhere else in Noe Valley. The service can be spotty but it's generally nice enough. Get a pineapple bran muffin and you'll be glad.
author: Casey W.

description: I love the fact that Martha's is no more than 50 steps away from my flat. I love the fact that they serve up consistently good - and unabashedly strong - coffee and espresso drinks.  I love the friendly family business vibe. I love the fact that a small vanilla latte packs enough punch to keep me going nearly all day. I love the overwhelming assortment of baked goods they stock on a regular basis, even though I rarely stray far from my usual chocolate almond cream cheese bread.  I love that they know that I usually order a small vanilla latte and a slice of the chocolate almond cream cheese bread.  I think I also love whoever came up with the idea for chocolate almond cream cheese bread.
author: Becca V.

description: Seriously- buy the Cappuccino Blend, grind it fresh and have it every morning. Its the best coffee in SF, screw Peet's! (not to metion starbucks, gross-ness!)
author: Daniel S.

description:
After a disappointing lunch down the street, I was walking to my car feeling not-quite satisfied, and Martha & Bros had attracted quite the usual SF outdoor crowd.  I walked right past, catching the faint smell of coffee, and made it all of ten feet beyond the property line before my senses kicked in and turned me back around.  Inside wasn't crowded at all (in fact there was no line at all).  Staff was helpful in helping me figure out what I needed.

I had their mochalatte with an extra shot (this is a blended drink with ice).  Unlike most places that just blend the extra shot in, they poured the extra shot in with the top 1/4 of the drink.  It also looks like the chocolate they're using is Ghiardelli, which is one step shy of crack cocaine for an addict like myself.

The result of this subtle difference over the green-aproned competition is remarkable: you get a drink that goes from bitter to sweet as you drink it (and as the dark espresso flows down through the frozen drink), literally good to the last drop and amazing for a drive out of the city on a hot day.

Sadly, as I live further down the bay in San Carlos, I probably won't get back here as often as I like -- but since my partner has a regular appointment in this area...it may mean one more good reason to take the drive in to "be nice".
author: Dan M.

description: I've walked by here a million times and there are always local-types standing around with their dogs and friends, chatting and drinking coffee. There is a Tully's and Starbucks within a couple blocks, so I figured it must be pretty good coffee to have such a loyal crowd. I got my usual latte, and it was great, and the service was very good too. It doesn't have the best layout for hanging out inside, and the condiments area is annoyingly far from where you pay and hard to navigate with more than one person. And they have no splenda!! All coffee places should have splenda. I would definitely get coffee here again, but only if i didn't want to hang out, and was just walking through.
author: Cyrelle D.

description:
From Sunup to Sunset, Martha's represents chitchat central for the entire 24th Street corridor.  Show up at eight and you'll find a little slice of Noe Valley seated on  the outdoor benches facing 24th Street.  Some people read the paper, some chat, and some just smile and soak up the morning sun while gazing southbound towards the San Bruno Mountains as their eyes convey a state of of blissful trance. Around nine things get crowded, and the bench area gets log-jammed with cantankerous codgers, doting parents, rambunctious toddlers,  and bagel-stealing dogs. Patrons run from young to old, and political views range from that of old-guard Socialists to Rush-quoting Reaganites.  Diverse opinions coexist peacefully for the most part...but when arguments heat up, it's fun to sit back and watch the sparks fly.  After 10AM or so the morning crowd moves out, but lunchtime brings a crowd of retirees and the conversation rages anew...

Standard issue pastries and muffins grace the indoor counter, and pre-made sandwiches make for a quick snack. Bagels and egg-based sandwiches are available just two doors down.  The coffee is a pleasant compromise between the watery blandness of Starbucks and the overpowering might of Peet's.  The creme-and-sugar stations is oddly located, but well stocked and rarely if ever runs out of half-and-half.  The staff is pleasant, quick, and remembers what you order if you're a regular.

Martha's on 24th Street is my morning hang where I read the paper, chat up the locals, and waste many a sunny morning.  If you're in the hood, check it out.  It's got all the pleasant nuances of a neighborhood pub, but with a cup of coffee priced at a buck-and-change instead of several pints of ale at $4.25 each.
author: Mike W.

description: I went in there on a Saturday morning and there was a line out the door, as usual. When it was finally my turn, I asked for a small coffee. The lady looked at me, then down to my belly (I'm 7 months pregnant) and said, "Decaf?" I said, "No, regular." She looked at me, gasped, and put her hands up. I was LIVID. That's never happened to me before. I was totally stunned and said, "It's for my husband (which it was) but that's none of your business." After I left, I was so pissed I didn't say more and cause a scene.
author: Jenny T.

description: This is *the* place for coffee in Noe Valley.  Please, please, for the love of God, skip the Starbucks and check out what the lovely, friendly ladies at Martha's have in store for you.  I go here about 4 times a week for strong coffee, good pastries, always happy smiling faces.  Cruise by on a Saturday before noon to experience the parade of strollers and onslaught of pedigree pooches for what can only be described as the quintessential Noe Valley Experience.
author: Cat T.

description: I don't understand why this place is so popular.  There are no comfy seats, and the coffee is weirdly spicy.  Bad spicy.  The Last Laugh is a much better choice.
author: Des Esseintes I.

description: I grew up coming to Martha's, starting back before it was even called Martha's, and now I work next door, so I have spent a good deal of time and money here. Everyone who works here is really friendly, including Martha herself. It is a little bit dark, and often too crowded, but that's not about to deter me from supporting this spot. The drinks and pastries are good, and the prepared sandwiches are decent. Very nice.
author: Aly S.

description: On Saturday mornings this is a congregation of locals chatting about friendships and children, flueling to cross the street for the farmer's market.  Service is very emotional - I've had an overly friendly with "a beautiful coffee for a beautiful girl" and "where did you go?!! sign here!!".  Must be all that strong coffee that brings out strong emotions.
author: Anya B.

description: MUCH stronger than Starbucks.  Really hits the spot.  Great biscottis too.
author: Rebecca E.

description:
I live just around the corner from this place so I visit often, even on my way home from work just to spend a few minutes to snack on a pasty and read a magazine.

Coffee is strong but tends to taste burned during the late afternoon hours. The pastries are okay and not overpriced. The seating is adequate and the front of the cafe gets a lot of light. Sometimes the music, when I'm sitting on a chair in the back of the cafe, is a bit loud but maybe the speakers are right over me...I never noticed where they are.

Seems to me that this is a regular hangout for lots of people. I see many of the same faces. The servers are quite nice and friendly.
author: tom g.

description:
Good place.  I don't especially love their coffee - I think it's better than most, but not my favorite.  Though to disclose, I am more of a Peet's person.
I don't like how they shout at you and you can't tell if you are being asked or someone else.
I don't like how sorta hectic it is in this place.
I HATE with a passion the disgusting spoon after it's been dipped by someone in their coffee and then put back into the sugar.  Come on Martha - figure a better way or just replace the spoon every once in awhile.
I don't like how there is never any seating and if so every table wobbles / etc.

However, they get points for good coffee, friendly service, and a good place to take coffee and run.
And I think they are way better than Starbucks and Tully's so kudo's to them.
author: Jonathan H.

description: The coffee was not bad. They burnt the milk for my au lait, and had the coffee minus milk sitting on the counter in the paper cup for awhile before bothering to ask the order taker "what is this?".  They also automatically put it in a paper cup, don't have wifi, and weren't friendly.  It does seem to be some sort of community center, but I am forced to say.... Martha Bros, Noe Valley is for old people - a different generation at least.
author: Heidi P.

description: The ladies who work at this location are so sweet.  They know all the regulars' names and drinks, work hard and are all smiles.  The coffee is better than average but not stellar.  My cappuccino the other day was quite delicious; you know how sometimes a cap can taste discordant (like espresso with a glug of milk) well this one was harmonious, topped with plenty of foamy goodness. And its 2 blocks from my place; the combo of quality service and convenient location is tough to beat.
author: Tina D.

description: Seriously, Martha's & Bros is not worth your energy.  By the time you finally manage to squeeze through the door that is blocked by strollers and dogs, the line is so slow moving that you forget why you came there in the first place.  Luckily, the menu on the wall clues you in but the wait just to get your favorite cup of coffee can be torture in itself.  Make your life easier and head down to Bernie's a few blocks away for your weekend morning coffee fix.  Unless you want to create more drama in your life why start your morning annoyed with the world.  I am sure that you have more important things to achieve.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
I live in the neighborhood so I frequent the place. The staff is always very friendly and welcoming, the coffee is pretty good and strong. Pastries are run of the mill, and if you're a Costco member you will recognize the products. 
Recently I noticed the "small" coffee  is sold now  in a cup as small as the spit cups you see next to sinks; price remained the same but the quantity is a joke; hate that kind of manipulation; did Martha and Brothers think their customers wouldn't notice? Also, this is an extremely popular and profitable business, free wi-fi would be the gracious thing to do since we all spend so much money there.
author: keiko s.

description: Excellent macchiatos and usually good beans. I usually get .5 lb of whatever they have on sale and grind and brew it at work so that I don't get tricked into going to our pricey coffee spot. The Cappucino roast is excellent, skip the Kona blend, which I thought was a little dry and flavorless. I can never make the espresso as good as they do, so I love stopping by there for a double macch on ice whenever I have an excuse.
author: Liboo K.

description:
Ahh Marthas - you were responsible for many a sleepless night until i discovered you did decaf espresso drinks! HURRAH
The coffee here is dark, rich and super strong! It is quite the best coffee I have had and I normally favour a milder roast! I find myself craving a Marthas coffee and when I go back to the UK I spit out the crappy, milky sh*t they serve us as my taste buds have learned to appreciate the fierce coffee life can bring you!!
There is always a queue here, and lots of Noe valley-ans arguing the toss about something or other on the sunlit benches outside! I come here quite often and find the staff friendly and efficient though have read that other people find them rude. I suspect these people themselves don't practice smiling or making conversation first and therein may be the problem. These guys are so busy and see so many people every day that unless you make the effort they just get on with serving the hordes who come through their doors to be caffeinated!!
Anyway, I think they are great and the coffee fantastic and the chocolate brownies are my nemesis! GOD THEY ARE GOOD!! And nut free which is great for one who is allergic to the damn things!!! YUM
author: Imogen d.

description: Coffee does not taste good, kinda like poo...Good thing they barely filled up my cup. Unfriendly staff, much rather spend my coffee money at Bernies!
author: John H.

description: love this place:  fantastic coffee, great selection of breakfast pastries, and probably the friendliest service you'll find in a coffee joint in the city.
author: Matt B.

description: yes, martha does care about the coffee's quality that she didn't hire me cuz my milk was "too cold" or "too hot" even though it was my 4th day and didn't have much training. she said she was gonna think about it....and so far she hasn't call me. and i doubt she'll pay me for training, too. but whatever....their coffee's alright by the way. i've tasted better.
author: JK R.

description: Friendly staff, good eats, and strong coffee. Too many people, always crowded, and a little pricey.
author: Jessie H.

description: I love this coffee shop, the coffee and espresso drinks have a great flavor unlike 'charbucks' - and when they recognize you day after day, they go out of their way to learn your name which makes all the difference.
author: J B.

description: A-OK, indeed. Nothing remarkable. A bunch of regulars sit on the benches outside, debating politics and the state of San Francisco. Apparently, things were all better in the old days. I don't enjoy the atmosphere much, lifeless inside, and the kid without friends outside. The coffee - acceptable.
author: Victoria A.

description: My birthday girl! (we have the same birthday) Despite that and being a sweetheart, she gets five stars. Any coffee that makes your fingernails sweat must be good. Right? Her signature blend is very good.
author: Jeff B.
